author: Riccardo Saporiti
title: Ghiacci polari, secondo i dati di Copernicus i livelli sono ai minimi storici
text:
Il mese di febbraio 2025 ha fatto segnare un record negativo per l'estensione dei ghiacci polari. A dirlo è l'agenzia europea Copernicus nel suo bollettino mensile dedicato alla crisi del clima. Un documento che segnala anche come quello che si è chiuso da pochi giorni è stato il terzo mese di febbraio più caldo di sempre.
La superficie dei ghiacci polari
Nello scorso mese di febbraio le dimensioni della calotta antartica hanno raggiunto un valore inferiore dell'8% rispetto alla media. Va detto che non si tratta di un record minimo per quel che riguarda il cosiddetto polo Nord, dal momento che è in questa stagione che il ghiaccio artico raggiunge le sue dimensioni massime. Se però di solito a febbraio arrivava a 100, volendo semplificare, quest'anno si è fermato a 92.
In Antartide, invece, la superficie coperta dal ghiaccio è inferiore del 26% rispetto a quella che mediamente si registra a febbraio. Mese che, nell'emisfero australe, rappresenta quello che agosto è in quello boreale. Guardando al dato complessivo, ecco la tendenza degli ultimi cinquant'anni:
Il grafico mostra l'andamento del global sea ice extent, indice che misura l'estensione dei ghiacci nelle regioni polari. Un valore che a febbraio ha raggiunto il record negativo di 16,18 milioni di metri quadrati. Nel febbraio 1979, il valore più antico disponibile per il secondo mese dell'anno, si era fermato a 19,56 milioni di metri quadrati. Si tratta di una riduzione del 17,3%.
L'andamento della temperatura
Con una temperatura media mensile globale pari a 13,36°C, il mese di febbraio è stato il terzo più caldo da che si registrano le temperature. Non solo: ha superato di 1,59°C la temperatura media del periodo preindustriale (1850-1900), quando gli accordi di Parigi impegnavano i paesi firmatari a sforzarsi per non superare di 1,5°C questa soglia.
La temperatura media globale dell'inverno boreale, ovvero del periodo compreso tra dicembre 2024 e febbraio 2025, è stata la seconda più alta mai registrata. Ed ha superato di 0,71°C la media del periodo 1991-2020.
La situazione in Italia
Utilizzando i dati forniti da Copernicus, è possibile visualizzare la situazione della temperatura in Italia. Questa mappa mostra la variazione rispetto alla media del periodo 1990-2020 della temperatura media mensile registrata a due metri dal suolo. I valori in rosso indicano un aumento più significativo della temperatura.
Le situazione più grave in termini di variazione in aumento rispetto alla media di riferimento, con punte di addirittura 4 gradi centigradi, si sono registrate nelle alpi Graie, tra la Valle d'Aosta e la provincia di Torino, e in Valtellina, ovvero in provincia di Sondrio (Lombardia).

author: @TIMESNOW
title: Struggling To Lose Weight? Your Afternoon Nap Might Be The Reason - Expert Explains How
text:
Struggling To Lose Weight? Your Afternoon Nap Might Be The Reason - Expert Explains How
Afternoon naps might feel refreshing, but sleeping for too long post-lunch can slow metabolism and lead to weight gain, says a nutritionist. Research links extended naps to high BMI, heart disease, and diabetes. Experts recommend limiting naps to 30 minutes and staying active afterwards to maintain a healthy weight. Read on to know more.
Struggling To Lose Weight? Your Afternoon Nap Might Be The Reason - Expert Explains How (Image Credits: iStock)
We've all been there—after a big, satisfying lunch, that wave of laziness hits, and the couch starts looking way too inviting. A quick afternoon nap feels like the perfect fix, right? It might help you recharge, but did you know that sleeping too long in the afternoon could actually lead to weight gain?
According to Dr Shikha Singh, a Certified Clinical Nutritionist, as per her Instagram bio, long post-lunch naps can slow down metabolism, making it harder to lose weight—even if you're dieting. Plus, they can mess with your sleep schedule, leading to late-night cravings and overeating. Sounds like a recipe for weight gain, doesn't it?
So, if you love your afternoon naps but also want to stay fit, keep reading to find out how to nap the right way without packing extra pounds!
How Do Afternoon Naps Cause Weight Gain?
Dr Singh pointed out that research suggests a 23 per cent higher likelihood of weight gain due to frequent afternoon naps. Here’s why:
1. Slow Metabolism – If you sleep for more than 30 minutes in the afternoon, your metabolism slows down significantly. This means that even with a proper diet, weight loss becomes much slower.
2. Disrupts Sleep Cycle – Long naps interfere with nighttime sleep, making it harder to fall asleep on time.
3. Increases Late-Night Cravings – Poor sleep leads to late-night hunger, which often results in overeating unhealthy snacks.
4. Raises Health Risks – A 2023 study published in the journal Obesity found that midday naps of more than 30 minutes are associated with higher body mass index (BMI), high blood pressure, and an increased risk of heart disease and diabetes.
How Long Should You Nap?According to Dr Singh, the ideal nap duration is 30 minutes or less. This short nap refreshes the body without slowing down metabolism. After waking up, she recommends stretching or walking for 5-10 minutes to keep the body active and boost metabolism.
Healthy Ways to Lose Weight
If long afternoon naps are slowing your weight loss progress, here are some effective ways to shed extra pounds:1. Stay Active Throughout the Day- Avoid sitting for long hours. Stand up, stretch, and take short walks every hour.
- Engage in at least 30 minutes of physical activity daily, such as brisk walking, yoga, or strength training.
2. Eat a Balanced Diet
- Include protein-rich foods like eggs, chicken, lentils, and nuts to keep you full for longer.- Increase fibre intake through fruits, vegetables, and whole grains to improve digestion.
- Reduce sugar and processed foods to avoid unnecessary calorie intake.
3. Stay Hydrated
- Drinking enough water prevents dehydration and unnecessary cravings.- Warm water or herbal teas after meals aid digestion and metabolism.
4. Get Quality Sleep- Poor sleep leads to increased hunger hormones, making you crave high-calorie foods.
- Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep at night and keep your naps short.
5. Manage Stress
- Stress leads to emotional eating and weight gain.- Practice deep breathing, meditation, or light exercises to reduce stress levels.

author: Diana León
title: ‘20 días en Mariupol’, el primer Premio Oscar para Ucrania
text:
El logro de haber documentado el inicio de la invasión rusa a Ucrania, le otorgó a ese país su primer Premio Oscar, a través del director Mstyslav Chernov.
Pero la emoción del triunfo se volvió agridulce durante su discurso de agradecimiento al recordar el material del que está hecho el documental: el inicio del conflicto armado que aún no termina.
“Desearía poder intercambiar esto por que Rusia nunca ataque a Ucrania, nunca ocupe nuestras ciudades. Desearía dar todo el reconocimiento a Rusia por no matar a decenas de miles de mis conciudadanos. (...) pero no puedo cambiar la historia, no puedo cambiar el pasado”, expresó.
Publicidad
“Pero todos juntos, ustedes –algunas de las personas más talentosas del mundo– podemos asegurarnos de que la historia se enderece y que la verdad prevalezca y que el pueblo de Mariupol y aquellos que han perdido la vida nunca sean olvidados. Porque el cine forma recuerdos y los recuerdos forman la historia”.

author: Bhutan's Daily Newspaper
title: Bhutan’s potential to lead global energy transition: BIF | Kuensel Online
text:
Dechen Dolkar
Bhutan has a unique opportunity to contribute to the global energy transition due to its abundant hydroelectric potential, rich cultural heritage, focus on mindfulness, and unwavering commitment to sustainability.
On the final day of Bhutan Innovative Forum at Dungkar Dzong in Paro, renowned mining magnate Robert Friedland, founder of Ivanhoe Mines, highlighted Bhutan’s dual challenges and opportunities in the space of clean energy.
“Bhutan has the potential to become a global leader in clean energy and sustainable development,” he said, while praising the country’s unique position in the region and the vision of its enlightened King.
He said that Bhutan is nominally now a carbon-negative country, but it has enormous challenges. “The hydroelectric potential is quite green in power compared to the alternatives.”
With a hydroelectric generation capacity of 2.5 gigawatts—equivalent to three and a half nuclear power plants—Bhutan produces green energy that surpasses many alternatives. However, during the dry winter months, the country must rely on electricity imports from India to meet its energy needs.
Robert Friedland said that by scaling up its hydroelectric capacity, Bhutan can establish a domestic green economy, a knowledge-based economy, and a thriving financial hub.
He said a future where Bhutan becomes a global hub for sustainable development, attracting investment and talent from around the world.
He shared insights from his experiences in 64 countries, expressing admiration for the unique challenges and opportunities faced by Bhutan under the guidance of His Majesty the King.
He stressed the importance of retaining young talent to drive economic growth and improve the lives of its citizens. “We are talking about so much is about opportunities and retaining the youth of Bhutan and keeping them in the country and creating wealth for everybody,” he said.
While acknowledging the significance of hydroelectric power, Robert Friedland also advocated for diversification of energy sources. “We need to explore other renewable energy options like solar and wind power,” he said. “But most importantly, we need to invest in technology and innovation to ensure a sustainable energy future.”
He also said that it is important to preserve Bhutan’s cultural heritage and natural environment. He urged the country to promote mindfulness and meditation as a way to foster a peaceful and harmonious society.
As the world shifts toward renewable energy to meet net-zero emissions targets, copper has emerged as a critical material due to its exceptional conductivity and versatility. It plays an essential role in developing renewable technologies such as solar panels, wind turbines, and electric vehicles, and is crucial for the transmission and distribution of electricity.
Robert Friedland said that for Bhutan, where hydropower constitutes a significant part of the economy and energy infrastructure, the demand for copper in the development and maintenance of this clean energy source will only continue to grow.
To meet the global net-zero targets by 2050, the world will need an estimated three to four times more copper than is currently produced, he said. This unprecedented demand underscores the need for sustainable mining practices and innovative solutions to manage the supply of critical minerals.
